article.title: $P-v$ criticality of a specific black hole in $f(R)$ gravity coupled with Yang-Mills field

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the P-r diagram in Figure 1 depict for a specific black hole (SBH) in f(R) gravity coupled with the Yang-Mills field (YMF)?
choices: The relationship between entropy and temperature at different pressures.
The behavior of pressure with respect to the black hole radius at different temperatures.
The change in specific volume as a function of pressure at constant temperature.
The phase transition between a small and large black hole at the critical point.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (24):  Pc/ (Pc * vc) = 3/8 * (Tc) \n\nQuestion 2:  Formula (24) represents a relationship derived for the SBH in f(R) gravity coupled with YMF. What is significant about this relation?
choices: It defines the critical temperature as a function of the black hole mass and charge.
It establishes the equivalence of pressure and temperature at the critical point.
It demonstrates a deviation from the behavior observed in Van der Waals fluids.
It highlights a similarity with the Van der Waals equation for liquid-gas systems.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the G-T diagram in Figure 3 illustrate for the SBH in f(R) gravity coupled with YMF?
choices: The stability of different black hole sizes at various temperatures.
The relationship between Gibbs free energy and entropy at constant pressure.
The change in Gibbs free energy with respect to temperature at different pressures.
The point of phase transition from a large black hole to a small black hole.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (1): P = -Λ / 8π =  - Λ l² / 8π  \n\nQuestion 4:  Formula (1) presents an important concept used in analyzing the thermodynamics of black holes. What does this formula represent?
choices: It defines the cosmological constant as a function of the black hole\'s mass and charge.
It establishes the relationship between pressure and temperature at the event horizon.
It introduces the concept of treating the cosmological constant as thermodynamic pressure.
It calculates the entropy of a black hole based on its surface area and gravitational constant.
